question: Why do your apps require Google Play Services?
answer:
My apps integrate several components from Google Play Services because they provide reliable, well-maintained solutions for everyday needs:

  • Firebase Analytics, Performance, and Crashlytics help monitor stability and feature adoption.
  • Google Ads / AdMob offset hosting, tooling, and device testing costs.
  • In-App Reviews & Play In-App Updates ensure a smoother experience without manual store checks.

Replacing these SDKs would mean rewriting entire systems and losing important telemetry, so the Play Store build remains the most sustainable choice.

question: Why aren’t your apps on F-Droid or other stores?
answer:
I appreciate the open-source philosophy of F-Droid and similar platforms, but their policies prohibit binaries that include proprietary SDKs such as Play Services, AdMob, or Firebase.

These SDKs are essential to my workflow, so the apps would not pass F-Droid’s checks. To avoid fragmented or unverified builds, I focus on:

  • Google Play Store for the primary, auto-updated release.
  • GitHub Releases for developers who prefer sideloading.

question: Will you ever make GMS-free or F-Droid builds?
answer:
I have experimented with lightweight, offline-friendly prototypes. The difficulty is maintaining two separate pipelines, testing matrices, and documentation — effectively doubling the workload for every update.

For now, concentrating on one Play Services–based build lets me ship features and fixes faster. If a sustainable path to a GMS-free edition appears, I will share updates in the news feed and on GitHub.

question: Where can I find official builds?
answer:
Download authentic, verified builds only from:

  • Google Play Store – primary distribution with automatic updates.
  • GitHub Releases – direct sideloadable builds from me.

APK mirrors may host outdated or modified packages. Always refer back to these official sources.
